[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.1 Purpose: The Meeting Room Scheduling System (MRSS) defines requirements to ensure compliance, usability, and efficiency in managing office space reservations.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.2 Scope: MRSS handles scheduling, resource allocation, and notifications with corporate integration.

[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.1 System Interfaces: MRSS integrates with multiple database management systems and corporate email servers.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.2 User Interfaces: MRSS provides a customizable UI aligned with corporate branding.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.3 Hardware Interfaces: MRSS supports desktops, tablets, and mobile devices within office environments.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.4 Software Interfaces: MRSS uses J2SE/J2EE libraries and RESTful APIs for data exchange.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.5 Communications Interfa: MRSS uses HTTPS/TLS 1.3 for secure communication.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.6 Memory Constraints: MRSS is optimized for handling high-volume transactions.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.7 Operations: MRSS maintains 99.99% uptime, excluding scheduled maintenance.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.8 Site Adaptation Requir: MRSS supports multilingual settings and accessibility compliance.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.9 Interfaces with Servic: MRSS links to scheduling, notification, and corporate database systems.

[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.4 Product Functions: MRSS manages room scheduling, notifications, and resources in real time.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.5 User Characteristics: MRSS serves employees, admins, and facility managers.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.6 Limitations: MRSS requires stable network connectivity and corporate authentication for access.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.7 Assumptions and Dependencie: MRSS relies on DBMS, email, and web servers.
[SUBSEC] 1.8 Definitions: Conference Schedule: Reserved and available meeting rooms.
Resource Allocation: Assignment of meeting equipment and amenities.

[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-001: The system shall interface with Oracle, SQL Server, and MySQL databases for room availability data.
[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-002: The system shall connect to corporate email servers to send meeting notifications.

[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-001: The system shall allow employees to reserve conference rooms and notify attendees via email (REQ-INTF-002).
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-002: The system shall enable administrators to manage meeting schedules, room availability, and resource allocation (REQ-INTF-001).
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-003: The system shall display available rooms by time, location, and capacity.

[SUBSEC] 2.3 Usability Requirements.REQ-USAB-001: The UI shall be intuitive with standard navigation and scheduling.
[SUBSEC] 2.3 Usability Requirements.REQ-USAB-002: The system shall allow employees to customize room booking preferences and notification settings.

[SUBSEC] 2.4 Performance Requirements.REQ-PERF-001: The system shall complete 90% of scheduling tasks within 5 seconds and 98% within 8 seconds.
[SUBSEC] 2.4 Performance Requirements.REQ-PERF-002: The system shall process 10,000 hourly transactions, scaling to 20,000.

[SUBSEC] 2.5 Logical Database Requiremen.REQ-DB-001: The system shall store room availability, schedules, and resources.

[SUBSEC] 2.6 Design Constraints.REQ-DSGN-001: The system shall be developed following corporate coding best practices and software design patterns.
[SUBSEC] 2.6 Design Constraints.REQ-DSGN-002: The system shall support multiple database management systems without reconfiguration.

[SUBSEC] 2.7 Standards Compliance.REQ-COMP-001: The system shall comply with the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and corporate security policies.

[SUBSEC] 2.8 Software System Attributes.REQ-ATTR-001: The system shall support automatic software updates to address emerging security vulnerabilities.

[SEC] 3. Verification: Tests scheduling, UI, and security compliance.
[SEC] 4. Supporting Information: Corporate compliance guidelines and UI standards.
[SEC] 5. References: ADA compliance, corporate security policies, and software best practices.
